text: i'm playing around with algebra of graphics, and it's pretty cool.  but I was surprised to find that plotting a categorical variable (a strong) on the x axis produced meaningless numerical labels instead of labeling the numerical value for each level with the actual level...is that expected?

elements.text: i'm playing around with algebra of graphics, and it's pretty cool.  but I was surprised to find that plotting a categorical variable (a strong) on the x axis produced meaningless numerical labels instead of labeling the numerical value for each level with the actual level...is that expected?

text: I’m new, so I’m not sure if that’s expected in algebra of graphics… But the solution to my above question (regarding plain Makie) might serve as a work-around while you wait.

elements.text: I’m new, so I’m not sure if that’s expected in algebra of graphics… But the solution to my above question (regarding plain Makie) might serve as a work-around while you wait.

text: Thanks for reporting, definitely not expected... There were a few changes in AbstractPlotting.jl regarding ticks and categorical variables and probably it broke.

elements.text: Thanks for reporting, definitely not expected... There were a few changes in AbstractPlotting.jl regarding ticks and categorical variables and probably it broke.

text: I confess I'm not sure if AlgebraOfGraphics is using internals of AbstractPlotting (so that minor changes in AbstractPlotting break it) or if AbstractPlotting is a bit loose with semver, but these compatibilities guarantees are kind of hard to follow with plotting packages

elements.text: I confess I'm not sure if AlgebraOfGraphics is using internals of AbstractPlotting (so that minor changes in AbstractPlotting break it) or if AbstractPlotting is a bit loose with semver, but these compatibilities guarantees are kind of hard to follow with plotting packages

text: If I finally get around to completely decouple processing and rendering, the rendering part could maybe live in AbstractPlotting and get tested with the AbstractPlotting CI

elements.text: If I finally get around to completely decouple processing and rendering, the rendering part could maybe live in AbstractPlotting and get tested with the AbstractPlotting CI

text: (on the plus side, AbstractPlotting improved a lot lately, so the rendering code can probably be simplified a lot)
